Content:: The COVID-19 pandemic in the U.S. state of Rhode Island is part of an ongoing worldwide viral pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), a novel infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). As of July 27, 2022, there has been 409,731 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Rhode Island, 60 of which are currently hospitalized, and 3,630 reported deaths. Rhode Island's COVID-19 case rate and death rate per capita are the highest and twentieth highest, respectively, of the fifty states since the start of the pandemic.[1][2] As of July 27, 2022, 1,069,902 Rhode Islanders have received at least one COVID-19 vaccine dose (equivalent to over 99% of the state's population) with 899,689 Rhode Islanders completing the primary vaccine series (equivalent to 85.15% of the state's population), and 446,124 Rhode Islanders receiving at least one booster dose (equivalent to 42.22% of the state's population).[3][4] As of July 27, 2022, there have been 146,869 breakthrough COVID-19 cases (48.49% of new cases since the beginning of vaccine rollout and 16.32% of vaccinated Rhode Islanders), 3,151 breakthrough hospitalizations (32.07% of new hospitalizations since the beginning of vaccine rollout and 0.35% of vaccinated Rhode Islanders), and 480 breakthrough deaths (33.15% of new deaths since the beginning of vaccine rollout and 0.05% of vaccinated Rhode Islanders).[5] Source: Rhode Island Department of Health
